Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: SC2: PHY-Layer-Integrated Collaborative Learning in Spectrum Coordination

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
With the explosion of wireless devices, spectrum is becoming a scarce resource that wireless systems fiercely compete for. To ensure that future civilian and military systems, ranging from connected Internet of Things (IoT) devices to battlefield ad-hoc networks, continue to support services with growing quality, systems must evolve beyond the traditional spectrum licensing model and towards an intelligent spectrum sharing paradigm, in which networks nodes collaborate to efficiently share the spectrum. This radical paradigm shift requires the integration of the latest machine learning advances with the more recent progress in software defined radio, in order to endow wireless devices with the intelligence and agility necessary to realize the vision of efficient unsupervised spectrum sharing. The proposed research aims at addressing this fundamental issue, and will offer ample opportunities to provide interdisciplinary training of students at the intersection of machine learning and communications engineering.

The project envisions a paradigm shift in radio design, which will intertwine agile communications engineering techniques with advanced machine learning algorithms to fuse the traditional physical-layer and link layers into a "collaboration layer". Specifically, the approach comprises three key elements: (1) a multi-carrier modulation format at the physical layer that provides the required agility to react to interfering signals; (2) a high-performing modulation recognition software that exploits the latest advances in deep learning and convolutional neural networks to accurately classify the radio frequency signals in the environment; and (3) a decision module exploiting the latest advances in regret minimization online algorithms to achieve high exploration versus exploitation performance in the wireless environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the participation of the Georgia Tech - Agile Communication Architectures (GT-ACA) Team in the DARPA Spectrum Collaboration Challenge (SC2). As per DARPA’s definition “the DARPA Spectrum Collaboration Challenge (SC2) is the first-of-its-kind collaborative machine-learning competition to overcome scarcity in the Radio Frequency (RF) spectrum." In layman's terms, this challenge is about enabling more radios (such as e.g., smart phones, IoT devices, etc) to share the spectrum through the use of collaboration mechanisms.
The GT-ACA Team qualified for the challenge as an “Open-Track Team,” after successfully passing three hurdles. The three hurdles tested the team's ability to master (i) the use of reconfigurable radio through the demodulation of packets in a DARPA-specified protocol, (ii) the understanding of the RF environment through the supervised classification of several modulation formats, and (iii) reasoning and contextualization through a machine learning problem abstracting spectrum access. The proposed approach envisioned a paradigm shift in radio design, by which intelligence and agility would be pushed closer to the physical (PHY) layer than ever before, i.e., the collaboration mechanisms would be an intrinsic part of the radio.
The project also offered training opportunities for two graduate students, as well as undergraduate students who worked on several aspects of the SDR infrastructure. Most importantly, we leveraged the Vertically Integrated Program at Georgia Tech and our VIP team called "Agile Communication Architectures" whose goal is to work on the integration of machine learning in communication systems. Over the last year, the VIP team grew from 9 undergraduate students to 20 students, across several departments, from freshmen to seniors.
